questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision, severe headache, and ringing in the ears for 4 months. questions.text: A 6-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatric department for routine vaccination. After the vaccination, the mother took the baby to the doctor as she noticed the baby's asymmetrically flat head and uneven ears . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this infant?
questions.explanation:
Anencephaly

Skull bones are absent and the brain parenchyma is exposed.

Brachycephaly

Due to premature closure of bilateral coronal sutures.

Dolichocephaly

Premature closure of the sagittal suture; produces a long and narrow skull, also known as scaphocephaly.

Plagiocephaly

Asymmetrical distortion or flattening of one side of the skull

Turricephaly

Cone-shaped head caused by premature fusion of coronal, sphenofrontal, and frontoethmoidal sutures

Trigonocephaly

Caused by premature fusion of metopic suture → Keel-shaped forehead and hypotelorism.

questions.text: A 20-day-old infant girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother with complaints of fever, vomiting, and diarrhea for four hours. questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and cough. He is vitally stable. On examination, right lower lobe crepitation is heard. A 4-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by his mother with the complaint of frequent falls. The patient was born prematurely at 36 weeks gestation via normal vaginal delivery, and there was no known history of cyanosis in the neonatal period. He has met all the developmental milestones. He is up to date with his current vaccination. examination reveals lower limb bowing and blue sclera. The diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta has been made. A 23-year-old male presents to the emergency department with abnormal movement of the limbs. The family members also complain of memory decline over the past few months. According to his mother, his father has similar symptoms, but these symptoms developed when his father was in his forties. The doctor suspected the phenomena whereby successive generations are in danger of developing diseases early and more severely. Which of the following term best describes this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Autosomal Dominant

Autosomal Recessive

Multiple spinocerebellar ataxias

Friedreich’s ataxia – GAA

Huntington’s disease – CAG

X-linked

Myotonic dystrophy – CTG

Fragile X Syndrome – CGG

Congenital dyskeratosis – TTAGGG (telomere repeating sequence)

No expression type

Crohn’s disease

Behcet’s disease

Genetic terms

Interpretation

Codominance

Both alleles contribute to the phenotype of the heterozygote.

 

EXAMPLE:

Blood groups A, B, AB; α1-antitrypsin deficiency; HLA groups.

Variable expressivity

Patients with the same genotype have varying phenotypes

 

EXAMPLE:

Two patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) may have varying disease severity

Incomplete penetrance

Not all individuals with the disease show the disease.

% penetrance × probability of inheriting genotype = risk of expressing phenotype.

 

EXAMPLE:

BRCA1 gene mutations do not always result in breast or ovarian cancer.

Pleiotropy

One gene contributes to multiple phenotypic effects.

 

EXAMPLE:

Untreated phenylketonuria (PKU) manifests with light skin, intellectual disability, musty body odour

Anticipation

Increased severity or earlier onset of disease in succeeding generations.

EXAMPLE:

Trinucleotide repeat diseases (e.g., Huntington's disease).

Loss of heterozygosity

If a patient inherits or develops a mutation in a tumour suppressor gene, the wild-type allele must be deleted/mutated/eliminated before cancer develops.

This is not true of oncogenes

 

EXAMPLE:

Retinoblastoma and the "two-hit hypothesis," Lynch syndrome (HNPCC), Li-Fraumeni syndrome

Epistasis

The allele of one gene affects the phenotypic expression of alleles in another gene

 

EXAMPLE:

Albinism, alopecia

Aneuploidy

An abnormal number of chromosomes; due to chromosomal nondisjunction during mitosis or meiosis.

 

EXAMPLE:

Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, oncogenesis

Mosaicism

Presence of genetically distinct cell lines in the same individual.

Somatic mosaicism—mutation arises from mitotic errors after fertilization and propagates through multiple tissues or organs.

Germline (gonadal) mosaicism—mutation only in egg or sperm cells. If parents and relatives do not have the disease, suspect gonadal (or germline) mosaicism

 

EXAMPLE:

McCune-Albright syndrome

Locus heterogeneity

Mutations at different loci result in the same disease.

 

EXAMPLE:

Albinism, retinitis pigmentosa, familial hypercholesteremia.

Allelic heterogeneity

Different mutations in the same locus result in the same disease

 

 

EXAMPLE:

β-thalassemia

Heteroplasmy

The presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA results in variable expression in mitochondrially inherited disease.

Uniparental disomy

Offspring receives 2 copies of a chromosome from 1 parent and no copies from the other parent.

HeterodIsomy (heterozygous) indicates meiosis I error.

IsodIsomy (homozygous) indicates a meiosis II error or postzygotic chromosomal duplication of one of a pair of chromosomes and loss of the other of the original pair.

EXAMPLE:

Examples: Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male underwent renal transplantation (in the right iliac fossa) in 2008 for chronic interstitial nephritis-related renal failure with the mother as a donor. He was treated with triple immunosuppression (cyclosporine, prednisolone and mycophenolate mofetil). The patient was normal till 2020, when he developed dull-aching , non-radiating right lower abdominal pain. A hard tumour (about 15 cm x 10 cm) was felt under the surgical scar in the right iliac fossa . Ultrasound-guided biopsy from the mass revealed mo nomorphic B-cell non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma . The blood's lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level was 850 U/L(normal: 140–280 units per litre). The 18FDG PET-CT was taken from the figure below. Serum creatinine was 1.10 mg/dl. It was diagnosed as a case of Post Transplant Lymphoma; it is caused by which of the following?

According to lab results, her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels are low, but her thyroid hormone (T3 and T4) levels are significantly higher. Which of the following disease pathways best describes the development of this patient's thyroid problem?

A 2-month-old Infant born to a 24-year-old human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) positive female via spontaneous vaginal delivery at her own residence was brought to the outpatient department for follow-up. Which of the following is a non-reliable method used for the diagnosis of HIV in this patient?

A professor was discussing the tumours of the cardiovascular system with medical students. After explaining the primary, secondary, benign and malignant tumours affecting the cardiovascular system, he mentions the most common tumour affecting the heart. Which of the following is the most commonest cardiac neoplasm in adults?

CARDIAC HEART TUMORS
PRIMARY (rare) SECONDARY (more common)

BENIGN

  1. MYXOMA
  2. RHABDOMYOMA

 

 
  • Secondary tumours/ Metastasis – Most common
  • The most frequent metastasis are from lung and breast carcinomas, melanomas, leukaemias, and lymphomas.

 MALIGNANT

  1. ANGIOSARCOMA
  2. RHABDOMYOSARCOMA
  • The most commonly affected cardiac tissue is the pericardium.

MEN-1 / WERMER SYNDROME

MEN-2B

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the physician with a complaint of excessive fatigue and jaundice . She reports that she had felt fatigued for months. questions.text: Which of the following is the only prokaryotic DNA polymerase with 5'→3' exonuclease activity ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - DNA polymerase I:

E.coli (Prokaryotic)

Eukaryotic

Function

DNA Polymerase I

Mitochondria

  • RNase
  • FEN-1 (Flap>endonyclease)
  • δ-polymerase (Minor role)

Nucleus

  • RNase H
  • FEN-1
  • Removes primer (5’ → 3' exonuclease activity)
  • Fill the gap (5’ → 3’ polymerase activity)

DNA Polymerase II
  • β(beta)
  • γ(gamma)
  • DNA proofreading and repair (5’ → 3’ polymerase and 3’ → 5' exonuclease activities)
  • Mitochondrial DNA synthesis

DNA Polymerase III
  • ε (Epsilon)
  • δ (Delta)
  • Leading strand synthesis
  • Lagging strand synthesis

DNA polymerase I

5’ → 3’ polymerase

 

Polymerisation

3' → 5' exonuclease

 

Proofreading

5' → 3' exonuclease

 

Removal of RNA primer, DNA repair, nick-translation

questions.text: The relation between intravesical pressure and volume can be studied by inserting a catheter, emptying the bladder, and then recording the pressure. At the same time, the bladder is filled with 50-mL increments of water or air (cytometry). A plot of intravesical pressure against the fluid volume in the bladder is called a Cystometrogram. Central diabetes insipidus is caused by a lack of ADH secretion. In a patient affected by severe lack of ADH secretion, which of the following parts of the tubule would have the lowest tubular fluid osmolarity?
questions.explanation:
HORMONE ACTION
Aldosterone Increases sodium reabsorption in ascending limb, distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct
Angiotensin II Increases sodium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, thick ascending limb, distal tubule and collecting duct (mainly in proximal convoluted tubule)
Antidiuretic hormone Increases water reabsorption in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.
Atrial natriuretic factor Decreases sodium reabsorption
Brain natriuretic factor Decreases sodium reabsorption
Parathormone Increases the reabsorption of calcium, magnesium and hydrogen and decreases phosphate reabsorption
Calcitonin Decreases calcium reabsorption

Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs), also known as estrogen receptor agonists/antagonists, are drugs that act on the estrogen receptor. A characteristic that distinguishes these substances from pure ER agonists and antagonists (that is, full agonists and silent antagonists) is that their action is different in various tissues, thereby granting the possibility to inhibit or stimulate estrogen-like action in various tissues selectively. Which of the following is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)?

A 32-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of feeling sad and having a decreased interest in previously enjoyed activities. The patient also reports feeling guilty and worthless, experiencing easy fatigability, and having difficulty concentrating. There have been significant changes in appetite and weight, with a 7% weight loss over the past month. The patient has been experiencing psychomotor retardation and has been having suicidal thoughts. On further questioning, the patient mentioned having difficulty falling asleep and waking up at least 2 hours before the usual time. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old patient presents with persistent sadness, loss of interest in activities, and decreased energy for the past few months. The patient also reports changes in appetite, weight loss, and difficulty sleeping. Based on the symptoms, the patient is diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Remission of Symptoms: The decision to discontinue SSRIs should be based on the achievement of remission, where the patient experiences a significant reduction or elimination of depressive symptoms. This typically involves a sustained period (often 6–12 months) of symptom stability.
  • ↳ Remission of Symptoms:
  • ↳ Assessment of Risk and Benefit: Consider the balance of risks and benefits. If a patient has experienced multiple episodes of depression or has a history of recurrent depression, the benefits of continued treatment may outweigh the risks.
  • ↳ Assessment of Risk and Benefit:
  • ↳ Gradual Tapering: When discontinuation is deemed appropriate, SSRIs should be tapered gradually to minimize the risk of withdrawal symptoms. Abrupt discontinuation can lead to discontinuation syndrome, characterized by flu-like symptoms, dizziness, and mood disturbances.
  • ↳ Gradual Tapering:
  • ↳ Patient Preferences and Collaboration: Discuss the decision with the patient, taking into account their preferences, concerns, and individual history. Collaborative decision-making enhances treatment adherence and patient satisfaction.
  • ↳ Patient Preferences and Collaboration:
  • ↳ Follow-Up Monitoring:
  • ↳ Follow-Up Monitoring:
  • ↳ Regular Monitoring: Regular follow-up appointments are essential during both the treatment and discontinuation phases. This allows for the assessment of symptoms, side effects, and the patient's overall well-being. Assessment of Relapse Risk: Evaluate the risk of relapse during follow-up. Individuals with a history of recurrent depression may benefit from extended or maintenance treatment to prevent future episodes. Psychoeducation: Provide ongoing psychoeducation to the patient about the nature of depression, the potential for recurrence, and the importance of early intervention if symptoms re-emerge. Individualized Treatment Plans: Tailor the follow-up schedule to the individual's needs. Some patients may require more frequent monitoring, especially during the early stages of treatment discontinuation. Collaborative Care: Engage in collaborative care with the patient's primary care physician or mental health provider to ensure comprehensive and coordinated management. Monitoring for Withdrawal Symptoms: During the tapering process and after discontinuation, be vigilant for withdrawal symptoms or signs of relapse. Adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

  • ↳ Regular Monitoring:

Pharmacotherapy

Main treatment for depression using antidepressants.

Duration

Maintain treatment for at least 6 months or the length of the previous episode, whichever is greater.

Drugs of Choice

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)

SSRIs

Sertraline, Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Citalopram, Escitalopram, Vilazodone, Fluvoxamine

Side Effects of SSRIs

GI issues, CNS effects, sexual dysfunction, haematological effects, miscellaneous effects

Serotonin Syndrome

Potential risk with concurrent use of SSRI and MAO inhibitors

Discontinuation Syndrome

Can occur with abrupt discontinuation of short-acting SSRIs

Vortioxetine

SSRI with additional receptor actions (5-HT1A agonist, 5-HT1B partial agonist, 5-HT1D antagonist)

SSRI and Pregnancy

Paroxetine should be avoided due to potential cardiovascular defect (Teratogenic)

Other SSRIs- Can be given, but increase risk of persistent pulmonary hypertension in infant (especially if given in 3rd trimester)

SSRIs

Main treatment for depression.

SNRIs

Dual reuptake inhibitors, potentially more effective in melancholic depression.

TCAs

Block serotonin and norepinephrine transporters.

MAOIs

Inhibit metabolism of monoamines.

Atypical Antidepressants

SARI (Serotonin Antagonist and Reuptake Inhibitor): Trazodone, Nefazodone;

NaSSA (Noradrenergic and Specific Serotonergic Antidepressant): Mirtazapine;

NRDI (Norepinephrine-Dopamine Reuptake Inhibitor): Bupropion;

NSRE (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Enhancer): Tianeptine.

Novel Agents

Esketamine: NMDA antagonist nasal spray for treatment-resistant depression.

Augmenting Agents

Lithium, atypical antipsychotics, thyroid hormone.

Psychotherapy

Description

Cognitive Behaviour Therapy

Corrects cognitive distortions and maladaptive behavior.

Interpersonal Therapy

Focuses on current interpersonal problems.

Family Therapy

Involves the whole family in therapy sessions.

Psychoanalytically-oriented Therapy

Explores unconscious conflicts and childhood experiences.

Behaviour Therapy

Modifies maladaptive behaviors through conditioning.

Somatic Modality

Description

Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)

Uses electrical currents to induce controlled seizures for treatment.

Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)

Applies magnetic pulses to stimulate nerve cells in the brain.

Vagal Nerve Stimulation

Stimulates the vagus nerve via implanted electrodes for treatment.

Deep Brain Stimulation

Involves implanting electrodes in specific brain areas to alleviate symptoms.

Phototherapy

Uses bright light exposure to treat seasonal affective disorder.

Sleep Deprivation

Temporary improvement in symptoms through controlled sleep restriction.

questions.text: Mr. Smith, an alcoholic, has stopped drinking for the past 24 hours. He presents with coarse tremors, nausea, and sweating. Which stage of alcohol withdrawal is he most likely experiencing?

options.label: A
options.text: Mild Symptoms (6-8 hours after stopping alcohol)

options.label: B
options.text: Moderate Symptoms (8-12 hours after stopping alcohol)

options.label: C
options.text: Severe Symptoms (12-24 hours after stopping alcohol)

options.label: D
options.text: Life-threatening Symptoms (within 72 hours after stopping alcohol)

questions.correct_answer: A. Mild Symptoms (6-8 hours after stopping alcohol)
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Mild Symptoms (6-8 hours after stopping alcohol)

Time Frame

Withdrawal Symptoms

6-8 hours after stopping alcohol

Tremulousness (coarse tremors/shaking), GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting), autonomic hyperactivity (anxiety arousal, sweating, mydriasis, tachycardia, hypertension)

8-12 hours after stopping alcohol

Alcoholic hallucinosis (hallucinations, auditory hallucinations more common, visual hallucinations may also occur)

12-24 hours after stopping alcohol

Seizures (generalized tonic-clonic seizures, may occur as cluster seizures)

Within 72 hours after stopping alcohol

Delirium Tremens (DTs) - Impaired consciousness, disorientation (to time, place, person), visual hallucinations (most common), auditory hallucinations, increased autonomic activity

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient is admitted to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset confusion, disorientation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness. His family reports that he was previously alert and oriented. The patient appears restless and exhibits inattention during the examination. The healthcare provider notices diffuse slowing of background activity on the patient's EEG. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient, and what would be the appropriate treatment choice?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Delirium; Antipsych

Assessment

Delirium

Confusion Assessment Method
  • Diagnostic tool to identify delirium
  • Focuses on acute onset, fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, altered level of consciousness

EEG (Electroencephalogram)
  • Diffuse slowing of background activity
  • Delirium caused by alcohol or sedative withdrawal may show low voltage fast activity

Mini-Mental State Examination
  • Cognitive function assessment tool
  • Can be used for delirium assessment

Treatment
  • Address the underlying cause of delirium
  • Physical support to prevent accidents
  • Regular orientation to time, place, and person
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol, olanzapine) for managing delusion, hallucination, agitation
    • Benzodiazepines for treating insomnia
    • Benzodiazepines as treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal delirium (Delirium tremens)

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the man, X ray images of her elbow, wrist and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.explanation:
Bone Region Epiphyseal Fusion Age (approximate)
Wrist (Lower end of radius & ulna) 17–18 years
Elbow (medial epicondyle, lateral epicondyle, capitulum, etc.) 14–16 years
Pelvis (iliac crest, ischial tuberosity) 18–21 years
Clavicle (medial end) 21–22 years (last to fuse)

Bone/Joint

Approximate Age of Fusion

X-ray Findings

Clavicle

Late teens to early 20s

Complete fusion of the medial and lateral ends.

Epiphyses of long bones

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the growth plates, disappearance of epiphyseal line.

Sternum

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the sternal body and manubrium.

Sacrum

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the sacral vertebrae.

Pubic symphysis

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the pubic bones, loss of symphyseal space.

Medial clavicular epiphysis

18-25 years

Fusion of the medial end of the clavicle.

Proximal humeral epiphysis

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the proximal humeral epiphysis.

Distal radius and ulna epiphyses

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the distal radial and ulnar epiphyses.

Distal tibial and fibular epiphyses

Late teens to early 20s

Fusion of the distal tibial and fibular epiphyses.

Lateral clavicular epiphysis

25-31 years

Fusion of the lateral end of the clavicle.

Epiphysis of long bones (certain exceptions)

Early 20s to late 20s

Fusion of specific epiphyses, such as those in the hand and foot.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a brownish-black, non-scaly macule on the palm of his hand. The lesion has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. On microscopic examination, fungal elements are observed. What is the most likely causative organism responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D- Exophiala werneck

Tinea Nigra

Description

Superficial fungal infection

Causative Organism

Exophiala werneckii/ Hortaea wernickii

Clinical Presentation
  • Brownish-black or dark brown macule on the palm or sole
  • Non-scaly, well-defined lesion
  • Gradual enlargement over time

Common Locations

Palms, soles

Microscopic Examination

Brown hyphae with light brown septa

Differential Diagnosis
  • Melanoma
  • Lentigo
  • Other pigmented skin lesions

Treatment
  • Topical antifungal agents (e.g., azoles, allylamines)
  • Oral antifungal agents (in severe or refractory cases)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of chronic plaque psoriasis presents with worsening symptoms . The patient reports increased erythema, scaling, and itchiness in her psoriatic plaques after stopping the treatment under stress as she was not noticing any improvement . Additionally, she notices that her plaques are spreading to previously unaffected area s . Her blood investigations reveal hypocalcemia. What term best describes the current state of her psoriasis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C- U

Aspect

Unstable Psoriasis

Clinical Features
  • Constitutional symptoms: Fever, Malaise, Pain, Tenderness

 

Two types:

  • Erythrodermic psoriasis
  • Pustular psoriasis

Aggravating Factors
  • Withdrawal of steroids
  • Coal tar
  • Pregnancy
  • Stress
  • Infections
  • - Hypocalcemia

Treatment
  • Oral steroids are completely contraindicated in Unstable psoriasis. Because they may lead to Rebound phenomenon.

questions.text: A patient presents with a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals. Which stage of syphilis does this presentation indicate, and what is the recommended medical treatment?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Primary syphilis, Benzath

Stage of Syphilis

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Diagnostic Features

Treatment

Primary Syphilis (Hard chancre)
  • Single painless ulcer (chancre) at the site of infection
  • Clean base and indurated (hard) borders
  • Highly infectious

  • B/L enlarged inguinal lymph nodes (Rubbery consistency)
  • Genital, anal, or oral chancre
  • Painless and may go unnoticed
  • Occurs 10-90 days after infection
  • Dark-field microscopy of exudate from chancre
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  •  Benzathine penicillin G (IM) 2.4 million units single dose.
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Widespread rash (maculopapular or pustular)
  • Fever, malaise, headache, sore throat
  • Lymphadenopathy (Characteristic - Epitrochlear group of lymph nodes)
  • Mucous membrane lesions
  • Moth eaten alopecia
  • Rash involving the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy
  • Condylomata lata (moist, flat-topped papules) in warm, moist areas
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Elevated liver enzymes, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) 

    2.4 million units single dose

Latent Syphilis
  • Asymptomatic
  • Early latent (within 1 year of infection) or late latent (more than 1 year after infection)
  • No visible symptoms
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM)
  • 2.4 million units single dose for early latent and 2.4 million units three doses once weekly for late latent syphilis.

Tertiary Syphilis
  • Late-stage complications affecting multiple organs
  • Gummas (soft, non-cancerous growths)
  • Cardiovascular syphilis (aortitis, aortic aneurysms)
  • Neurosyphilis (meningitis, paresis, tabes dorsalis)
  • Diverse clinical manifestations
  • Gummas in skin, bones, and internal organs
  • Neurological deficits, psychiatric symptoms
  • Aortic aneurysms, valvular insufficiencies
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR)
  • Cerebrospinal fluid abnormalities (if neurosyphilis suspected)
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) or Penicillin G (IV/IM) for neurosyphilis

Congenital Syphilis
  • Transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy
  • Various manifestations (hepatosplenomegaly, rash, bone deformities, Hutchinson teeth, saddle nose)
  • Infected infants at birth or develop symptoms within the first few months of life
  • Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., VDRL, RPR) in the infant or mother
  • Benzathine penicillin G (IM) for infants and pregnant mothers

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with atticoantral CSOM presents with extensive bone destruction involving the annulus, tympanic bone, ossicles, and tegmen tympani. Tubo-tympanic

Attico-Antral

Treatment of primary pathology

It can be treated with ear surgery depending on the extent of the disease.

It can be treated with reconstructive surgery like myringoplasty or tympanoplasty.

Modified radical mastoidectomy is commonly done.

 

Reconstructive surgery like myringoplasty, tympanoplasty and reconstruction of the ossicular chain can be performed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with back pain and stiffness. Imaging reveals involvement of the lower half of the T6 vertebra and the upper half of the T7 vertebra, along with the intervertebral disc in between. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Cause

Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria transmitted through inhalation of respiratory droplets from infected individuals.

Pathogenesis

Bacteria reach the spine through hematogenous spread from a primary infection site, usually the lungs, and cause granulomatous inflammation in the vertebral bodies.

Clinical Presentation

Gradual onset of symptoms, including back pain, spinal stiffness, loss of mobility, and possible neurological deficits if the spinal cord or nerves are compressed.

Diagnostic Evaluation

Combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies (X-rays, CT scans, MRI), and microbiological tests (acid-fast bacilli staining, culture, PCR) to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment

A combination of anti-tuberculosis medications (such as isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol and streptomycin) for a prolonged duration (often 9-12 months) to achieve complete eradication of the bacteria. Surgical intervention may be required in certain cases, especially for spinal instability or neurological compromise.

Prognosis

Early diagnosis and prompt initiation of treatment can lead to favorable outcomes. However, delayed or inadequate treatment can result in spinal deformity, neurological deficits, and chronic pain. Regular follow-up and adherence to the full course of anti-tuberculosis medication are essential for successful management.

Prevention

TB vaccination (BCG) and infection control measures, such as identifying and treating active cases promptly, implementing respiratory hygiene, and ensuring proper ventilation in healthcare settings.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ The " R-on-T phenomenon " is the superimposition of an ectopic beat on the T wave of a preceding beat which triggers Polymorphic VT. The superimposition of an ectopic beat on the T wave of a previous beat that causes Polymorphic VT is known as the "R-on-T phenomenon." Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), also referred to as the R on T phenomenon, are what cause torsades de pointes. Torsades begin before a series of brief-long R-R intervals known as pause-dependent TDP. There is sinus rhythm along with a lot of premature ventricular contractions in the pattern of ventricular bigeminy. The QT interval is considerably lengthened, and each PVC occurs on the previous T wave (R on T phenomenon). Atrial fibrosis brought on by earlier catheter ablation or following an atriotomy is visible in atrial tachycardias as a macro-reentrant circuit . The capacity to entrain tachycardia with fusion is a distinguishing feature of macro reentry. Early after depolarisation causes an aberrant repolarisation of an action potential, and it causes the normal repolarisation process to be interrupted or delayed. It's described as the typical repolarisation slowing down or turning around during the action potential's phase 2 or phase 3. This causes tachycardia, torsades de pointes, and other arrhythmias. options.text: Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, benign hepatic cysts, and shrunken kidneys

questions.correct_answer: B. Multiple cysts in the renal cortex and medulla bilaterally, benign hepatic cysts, and enlarged kidneys

questions.text: A 7-day-old male infant is brought in with a frequent history of apnea , each lasting 20–60 seconds, associated with bradycardia and alternating with hyperpnoea & abnormal eye movements . Physical examination & initial investigations are not significant. On further workup, an MRI of the brain shows characteristic molar tooth sign. Which of the following pathology is associated with the above syndrome?

A 10-month-old child is brought to the pediatric department with complaints of nausea and vomiting. The child is malnourished, along with mild to moderate dehydration. The child had a previous history of cerebral palsy at the 5 th month of age. Serum electrolytes and ABGs are also abnormal. Barter syndrome has been diagnosed in the child. Which of the following are associated with bartter syndrome ?

options.label: A
options.text: Urinary calcium increased, and Mineralocorticoid antagonists can not be used

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic acidosis is present, Mineralocorticoid antagonist cannot be used, and normal to low blood pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis and normal to low blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis, Mineralocorticoid antagonist can not be used and normal to low blood pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Urinary calcium increased, Hypokalemic alkalosis and normal to low blood pressure
questions.explanation:
Bartter's Syndrome  Gitelman's syndrome  The case 
1. Plasma  renin activity  ↑ ↑ ↑
2 Plasma aldosterone ↑ ↑ ↑
3 Serum K  ↓ ↓ ↓
4 Metabolic alkalosis present  Present  present
5 Blood pressure → or ↓ → or ↓  →
6 Response of blood pressure for angiotensin II infusion ↓ ↓ ↓
7 Juxtaglomerular apparatus Hyperplasia  Hyperplasia  Hyperplasia 
8 With other diseases   1)  Absent  Absent  Absent 
9 Serum Mg  → or ↓ ↓ ↓
10 Serum Ca → → →
11 Urinary ration of calcium to creatinine → or ↑ ↓ ↓
12 Response to furosemide test   2)  absent or little  present  present 
13 Response to thiazide test   3)  Present  absent or little  littel

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with chronic complaints of burning sensation and discomfort over the epigastrium. questions.text: A 67-year-old male complained of generalized fatigue associated with difficulty breathing. On examination, pallor & gingival hypertrophy is noted. Initial investigations revealed hyperleukocytosis. Follow-up investigations showed leukostasis. This feature is most predominantly seen in which of the following disorders?

A 78-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to the abrupt onset of difficulty in speaking for 1 hour. He has had a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus for 30 years and coronary artery disease for 10 years, treated with pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin and aspirin. His blood pressure is 165/90mmHg, his pulse is 76 beats/min, and temperature is 37.0°C. On physical examination, the patient speaks in short, simple sentences with difficulty repeating word sequences. He can follow simple instructions. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the patient’s condition?
What is the false regarding difference in between Upper motor neuron lesion and Lower motor neuron lesion?

A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic, reporting that she is late for her period by one day. She has been married for 4 years and has 2 children. She has no significant gynecological history. She has had regular periods. Her urine pregnancy test is negative. She is advised to wait for another few days and gets her period the next day. Which mechanism is responsible for menstrual bleeding in the absence of pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.

options.label: C
options.text: Estradiol levels are not involved in the LH surge phenomenon

options.label: D
options.text: Estradiol inhibits the induction of the progesterone receptor in the endometrium

questions.correct_answer: A. The involution of the corpus luteum causes estradiol and progesterone levels to fall dramatically.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient known case of PCOS who is being treated for infertility and was prescribed clomiphene citrate 20 days ago for ovulation induction has now presented with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension with ascites reported on abdominal ultrasound. What is the most probable cause of her symptoms?
Which hormone is responsible for the mid-cycle rise in body temperature in females?

A 37-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in her lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan, a complex ovarian cyst is 4 x 5 cm in size with a ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, and menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done, and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?

A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.correct_answer: A. Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

questions.text: Which blood test would be most helpful in establishing a diagnosis for a 20-year-old girl presenting with rapidly developing hirsutism, amenorrhea, voice changes, abdominal pain, and a single ovarian mass detected on ultrasound?

A 25-year-old female presents to the gynaecologist for counselling regarding cervical cancer screening. She has no family history of any gynaecological cancer. She is married and is not planning to conceive. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: She must have cervical cytology now and follow after 3 years

options.label: B
options.text: She must have cervical cytology with HPV testing now and follow up after 3 years

options.label: C
options.text: She must wait for 2 years, after which cervical cytology must be done

options.label: D
options.text: She does not need cervical cancer screening.

questions.correct_answer: A. She must have cervical cytology now and follow after 3 years

questions.text: An obese 49-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension complained of heavy menstrual bleeding and delayed and irregular cycles for the last 6 months. She is advised by TVS. Which of these is the most important cause that should be ruled out in this patient?
Review the following hysterosalpingogram and provide the appropriate diagnosis.

She has been married for 5 months. Her HSG reveals two separate cavities of the uterus, cervix and vagina. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A radiologist performing an obstetric ultrasound visualizes the placenta and calls it Grade III. Placental grading on ultrasound is based on following criteria:-

Grade 0

<18 weeks

uniform echogenicity

smooth chorionic plate

18-29 weeks

Scattered echogenicities and subtle chorionic plate undulations

30-38 weeks

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency department with intense, sudden onset pelvic pain and profuse bleeding after giving birth at home. Examination reveals a tender, mass protruding from the vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?

An Rh-negative woman at 23 weeks pregnancy presents with a history of abdominal trauma associated with vaginal bleeding. Ultrasound shows only a minor retroplacental bleed. The fetal heart and movements are good. The treating doctor, however, plans to give her an Anti-D injection and wishes to calculate the dose required, for which there is a need to know the amount of fetal RBCs that have crossed into the maternal circulation, if any. The detection ability of this test is based on which of the following concepts?

options.label: A
options.text: Adult erythrocytes are larger than those of the fetus

options.label: B
options.text: HbA has a higher oxygen affinity than HbF

options.label: C
options.text: HbF is more resistant to acid than HbA

options.label: D
options.text: HbA takes up erythrosin stain less than HbF

questions.correct_answer: C. HbF is more resistant to acid than HbA

questions.text: A pregnant woman with Rh negative blood group had a history of fall at home. Although there was no pain or bleeding per vaginum following it, she is anxious about the effects on her baby. Which of the following findings is NOT suggestive of fetal affection in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity

options.label: D
options.text: Doppler flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Decrease in middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity
questions.explanation:
Indicators of the fetal hemolysis
1-Increase in middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity
2- Doppler flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery
3- Hydrops fetalis on USG

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks gestation has abdomen larger than expected at 13 weeks on physical examination. An ultrasound reveals multiple gestations. Which of the following is the type of twin pregnancy shown in the ultrasound image?

In a 33 year old woman who conceived with IVF, an USG at 12 weeks shows a single developing fetus. The previous USG at 6 weeks showed a twin pregnancy. The patient has unremarkable medical history, takes only vitamins. Vital signs and physical examination are normal. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Advice medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) as the second twin is at increased risk of aborting

options.label: B
options.text: Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Watch for coagulation defects in the mother

questions.correct_answer: B. Continue pregnancy like a normal singleton pregnancy
questions.explanation: Correct Option B

Which of the following is the most common association with such presentation of the fetal head?

A case-control study is a type of observational study in which two existing groups differing in outcome are identified and compared on the basis of some supposed causal attribute. Case-control study method has the following three distinct features, Which of the following is the inappropriate one?

options.label: A
options.text: Both exposure and outcome occurred before the start of the study

options.label: B
options.text: The unit of study is a group rather than individual

options.label: C
options.text: The study proceeds backward from effect to cause

options.label: D
options.text: It uses a control or comparison group to support or refute an interference

questions.correct_answer: B. The unit of study is a group rather than individual

1 - 6 years of age 2 lakh IU orally

A 56-year-old male presented to the physician complaining of polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and weight loss. The physician suspected diabetes and a screening test was done. What will happen if the cut-off point for blood glucose is lowered to detect Diabetes (say less than 120 mg percent)?

options.label: A
options.text: Sensitivity of the test is increased

options.label: B
options.text: Specificity of the test is increased

options.label: C
options.text: Predictive accuracy of the test is decreased

questions.correct_answer: A. Sensitivity of the test is increased
